The Human Operating System: A Primer on Psychological Exploitation

This chapter focuses on the psychological aspects of social engineering within the context of Active Directory. This chapter also covers the psychological vulnerabilities attackers exploit, offensive tactics for gaining privileged access through manipulations, and defensive strategies that use psychological principles to fortify human and technical defenses.

  • Part I: The Human Operating System
    • Module 1: The Mind as a Threat Model
      • 1.1 Explain how cognitive biases and heuristics (e.g., trust, authority bias) make humans the weakest link in security.
      • 1.2 Explain the Psychological Principles: behind urgency, fear, and curiosity as social engineering drivers.
      • 1.3 Discuss the Psychology of the Target: personality types, roles, and susceptibility to manipulation.
    • Module 2: The Attackerâ€™s Toolkit
      • 2.1 Reconnaissance with a Psychological Edge: Explain how attackers build a psychological profile of their targets using publicly available information from social media and other sources.
      • 2.2 Crafting the Perfect Pretext: Discuss advanced pretexting, baiting, and quid pro quo scenarios tailored to specific roles within AD.
      • 2.3 The Art of Impersonation: Explain how using Deepfakes and advanced impersonation techniques create realistic and emotionally resonant attacks.

      • Part II: Active Directory: The Crown Jewels of Social Engineering

    • Module 3: The Active Directory Kill Chain with a Human Focus
      • 3.1 Map the human-centric stages of an attack on Active Directory, from initial access through reconnaissance to lateral movement.
      • 3.2 Explain how leveraging social engineering to bypass technical controls aids in obtaining initial foothold credentials.
      • 3.3 Explain how exploiting a victim's trust leads to pivoting into higher-privileged AD accounts.
    • Module 4: Privilege Escalation Through Persuasion
      • 4.1 The Helpdesk is a Dead Giveaway: Explain how targeting IT helpdesk personnel through psychological tactics aid in getting credentials or password resets for privileged accounts.
      • The Unconscious Administrator: Discuss techniques attackers use to trick system administrators into unknowingly performing an action (e.g., running a malicious script or approving a policy change) that facilitates an attack.
      • 4.3 Supply Chain as a Social Vector: Explain how manipulating a trusted third-party or vendor or contractor leads an attacker to gaining access to an organization's network and Active Directory.
    • Module 5: Deception in Plain Sight: Staying Undetected
      • 5.1 Blending In: Explain ways in which using social camouflage and psychological manipulation aids attackers in moving laterally within a network without arising suspicion giving examples of what attackers look for when searching for defensive barriers and tactics for defenders.
      • 5.2 Forging Trust: Simulate legitimate AD activities to create a deceptive trait that misleads blue teams and appears as normal user behavior.
      • 5.3 Adversary Playbook: Simulate advanced persistent threat (APT) that combines sophisticated technical exploits with patient, long-term social engineering.

      • Part III: The Psychology of Defensive Countermeasures

      • Module 6: Hardening the Human Firewall Chain
        • 6.1 Psychology-Based Security Awareness Training: Moving beyond standard, checklist-based training to simulate real-world, psychologically manipulative attacks.
        • <6.2 Building a "Questioning Culture:" Discuss ways to create an organizational culture where employees feel comfortable questioning suspicious requests without fear of repercussions.

        • 7.2 Manipulating the Attacker: Turning the Table: Create deceptive AD objects, trusts, and data that lure attackers into a controlled "deception environment" and discuss.
        • 7.3 Cognitive Load Defense: Explain how using sophisticated and realistic deceptions overwhelm an attacker's cognitive processing to increase their chance of making a mistake.
          • Module 8: The Adaptive Defense: Behavioral Analytics
            • 8.1 Psychological Baselines: Explain how using behavioral analytics to establish a normal pattern of user and administrator behaviors in AD, making it easier to spot subtle, psychologically driven anomalies.
            • 8.2 Predictive Psychology: Explain how to leverage machine learning to predict potential social engineering targets based on publicly available information and internal data.
            • 8.3 Responding with Empathy and Authority: Develop incident response playbooks that incorporate psychological best Practices for handling compromised employees and communicating during an attack.

How does it work?

We cannot transition height or any CSS property from zero to auto. If we want to smoothly expand a collapsed accordion, we could set a max-height and transition the height property to a large value when we expand the section. However, it may not properly work if the content is larger than the max-height.

So, here we create a CSS grid with a grid item. Then we transition the grid-template-rows property from 0fr to 1fr and the grid item transitions to its content height.

I used CSS clip-path and mix-blend-mode to animate the background and text color of the accordion. Each accordion has two pseudo-elements. We know that opacity, clip-path and, visibility are animatable CSS properties. So when the accordion is selected using the :target pseudo-class, we transition the clip-path circle radius to 200% of the ::before pseudo-element. When the accordion is not selected, we do the same with the ::after but this time with a delay. This creates an illusion as it appears to clip from inside.

Since the accordion's title is an anchor element, users can also navigate through the items with their keyboard.

Inspiration

In a recent video, Kevin showed us a way to animate height from zero to auto value. Seeing that, I couldn't resist experimenting with the idea. Then I came up with this CSS-only accordion component and added the reveal animation too!

I would highly recommend watching his video, where he beautifully explains the technique and points out how he discovered it. Also, read Keith J. Grant's post and Nelson Menezes's post on the same topic.
